prasenjitm wrote:
> Any talk of having a prioritization scheme in CandidateURIs and 
> WorkQueues as well ?  We would like to know the current ideas if any 
> exists.

The 'cost assignment' policies are a form of prioritization which,
depending on your settings, can affect both the order of URIs in
individual queues, and the amount of effort spent on a queue in
total.

Specifically, all other things being equal, URIs of higher 'cost'
are inserted further back in individual queues. The idea is that
proper choice of a cost assignment policy can make URIs of diminishing
value -- such as URIs with long calendar-like query-strings, or
matching other patterns to be determined -- 'high cost' and thus
uncrawled until other higher-value 'low cost' URIs are finished.

Further, a queue's chance to be 'active' (eligible to supply URIs
to waiting threads) versus 'inactive' (piled up among other waiting
queues) is controlled by the 'budgetting' settings:

Each URI completed results in a charge (of its 'cost') against its
queue's running budget; when the budget is depleted the queue must
wait again at the back of the 'inactive' queues for a chance to get a
replenished budget.

Since 'high cost' URIs deplete the budget faster, queues dominated
by such URIs will get less crawler attention -- as long as such
attention is being rationed by something other than the need to
be polite -- than other queues dominated by 'low cost' URIs.

It is also possible to use the overrides mechanism to set the
'replenish' amounts different for different hosts/domains -- so
some queues get more or less 'active' time compared to 'inactive'
time.

We believe these mechanisms have helped a saturated crawler spend
less time on junk/chaff, and we've used varying replenish budget
settings, in overrides and generally, to bias our crawlers towards
certain patterns of access. But we don't have any firm qualitative
data on the improvements they provide; it'd be a good area for some
controlled study.
